An experimental design using "background-clip: text" has now consumed well over 40 hours of my life and I've contributed to two OSS projects in the process—something I'd really done very little of prior. BUT! I just resolved what I needed to do, so I'm kind of excited at the moment.
@ericzanol Here's a modernizr test so you can add backgroundcliptext or no-backgroundcliptext as a class on <html> https://github.com/Modernizr/Modernizr/issues/199/#comment_791334
@ericzanol There *was* a test for this, but it no longer would work in FF4.
@ericzanol Primary reason for doing this, of course, is that background-clip: text does not fail gracefully at all.
I may blog about the method, but it's a side-project I'm doing with another developer, so I don't want to publish any of it until he launches the app. :)
Modernizr is a great feature detection toolkit.

No. It is only for detection, but really that's all you need (and want). A lot of people frequently seem to think it "modernizes" non-modern browsers, but it doesn't. It just very simply tells you what is supported and what isn't so if you have a feature or design element that you know will just look or work terribly, you get a handy flag for creating an alternative yourself or disabling that feature altogether for non-modern browsers.
@adambrault nice work. i don't know as much about modernizr as i should. it ships with html5boilerplate, no?
They're both Paul Irish + friends projects.
right
So you can say, "if it has this feature, let's use it and make it look/work this way—and if it doesn't, we'll get a flag and create an alternative."
does it create the alternative? or just the flag that trips the use of the alternative you have to create?
i see. sounds pretty useful, especially for apps.

  background-image: -webkit-gradient(linear,left top,left bottom,color-stop(0, $top),color-stop(1, $bottom)), $url

As Henrik pointed out here (https://twitter.com/henrikjoreteg/status/40824667249844224) — IE9's CSS3 support is kind of a joke.
**HULK SMASH!!**
and as the article henrik mentioned pointed out, it doesn't support the box-model decs
And apparently none of the SASS cross-browser helpfulness I've used before to get some of that stuff into IE—at least based on this article

"There are only a very few declarations in my test that IE9 does not support. CSS columns, gradients, text-shadow, resize, and text-stroke are the only ones, and the latter two are WebKit-only. Even better news: Microsoft’s filters seem to have just disappeared from IE9. It supports normal opacity; no more filters required. Also, the gradient filter is gone, leaving IE (temporarily?) not supporting it."
or border images
ppk's article is older though, so, yeah.
Our buddy Weston says— IE9 supports canvas, so can you use https://github.com/westonruter/css-gradients-via-canvas
looking at it.

Isn't CSS3 a joke? You can't really blame MS for not supporting working drafts of this crap. I'm all for progress and I'm gonna love on some CSS3 when I don't have to use -webkit this and -moz that. We love gadgets and tech, and want to be cutting edge, but the rest of the world and most audiences aren't as cutting edge as we are and would like them to be. MS caters to millions of the unwashed and non-tech savvy, and when you get right down to it, those people don't give a flying crap about webkit, safari, firefox betas or ie9's OpenGL support. Honestly, they're more likely to base a decision to use Firefox over IE because they believe that hackers are going to steal their money if they use it. And some 13 year old who likes computers is going to corroborate that story. Building to the highest common denominator and then shoehorning a project into the lowest provides a terrible user experience. Instead of degrading gracefully, maybe we should ascend beautifully eh?
You do realize that some of this stuff like border-radius works just fine without -webkit

@ianshea yeah. i guess i'm just wondering if it's possible for the ui to be so bad that it flips the entirety of the ux over to the terrible/unplanned side. and if it is possible, then my first question would be what else happened upstream that led to css support across browsers being the linchpin for the ux.
*...provides a terrible user experience* -- What I really mean here is that it provides a generally unplanned user experience that's been hacked together and forced into working as an afterthought.

yeah i generally like to go the progressive enhancement route. if your browser can't see the rounded corners, well, ok.

by "user experience," do you mean "user interface?"
@ericzanol Isn't the user experience made up partially by the user interface?
Also, ALL specs are a joke until someone actually takes a stab at an implementation.
I think some of the reasoning there is to not break old browsers. But I'm no CSS maestro :)
@HenrikJoreteg Of course. But, I won't be happy until there is no -webkit  :)

@ianshea Choosing an imperfect, closed, proprietary platform over an imperfect open platform is a little short-sighted as we actually have some ability to have an impact on the latter and it can only get better.
@ianshea Firebird/Firefox and the whole notion of web standards in general looked like a joke to most people in 2003.
@ianshea IE6 won and closed up shop.

@ianshea And I disagree with your last point about people not caring about those things. Users will ACTUALLY PAY CASH MONEH for newer hardware when someone tells them they need to in order to run software. It's silly to think we would be afraid of suggesting that a better experience on the web would be gained from using a modern browser. Web developers are just chicken. Every other platform has the guts to set some boundaries for their users.
You wouldn't use a 10 year old computer to run the latest game and you shouldn't use a 10 year old browser to view a modern website and expect an identical experience.
and a new browser that sucks is not the same as a browser that has been adopting the latest innovations
(for years)
And, really, I'm fine with 3-4 vendor prefixes. That's what CSS compilers like SASS are awesome for. :)

Adam very well put. I have been one of those chickens. I don't see any reason to do that anymore. And I have no problem with vendor prefixes. Sure it would be slightly less to type not having the vendor prefixes, but as you said with css compilers it is very minimal anyway.
Hey @adambrault whatup?
@ianshea YO!
Found this the other day! Helped me out a bit with some things recently: HTML5 Tech Specs for Web Devs http://developers.whatwg.org/
@ianshea nice.
